Metadata: Plasma testosterone concentration predicts the ovulatory response of coho salmon ("Oncorhynchus kisutch") to gonadotropin-​releasing hormone analog
"Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences," 44(7):1351-​1357, 1987.

Plasma concentrations of testosterone, 17 "alpha"-​hydroxy-​20"Beta"-​dihydroprogeste​rone (DHP), and estradiol-​17"beta" were determined in hatchery populations of adult female coho salmon before and after the fish were injected with gonadotropin-​releasing hormone analog (GnRHa) to accelerate ovulation. Treatment with GnRHa significantly accelerated maturation over that observed in controls; however, a number of females did not ovulate for as long as 8 weeks after treatment. Testosterone was always higher before treatment in the early-ovulating fish and may be useful for predicting the sensitivity of coho salmon to GnRHa treatment for induced ovulation.
